english.park_text: Today we went to the park. The sun was shining. We played on the swings and had fun.
english.birthday_text: It was my birthday last week. I got a big cake and balloons. My friends came to play with me.

english.morning_with_dog_text: My dog is very playful. He runs fast in the park every morning and loves chasing butterflies.
english.washing_car_text: Every Saturday, Dad washes the car carefully. He uses a sponge, water, and soap to make it shine.
english.reading_library_text: We visit the library every week. I enjoy sitting with my friends and reading stories about space and animals.

title: Karaoke Sentences
school_q1: Should I tell the school about my child‚Äôs condition?
school_a1: Yes, it's very important that teachers know the challenges your child is facing to provide the right support.
school_q2: But I'm afraid they might be bullied or labeled.
school_a2: Your child has the right to receive educational accommodations. You can agree with the school on confidentiality.
school_q3: How do I start the conversation with them?
school_a3: Start by sharing the observations you‚Äôve noticed, and ask to schedule a meeting with the counselor or educational specialist.
school_a4: Working with the school opens many doors to success for your child, and eases the pressure on you too.
school_end_message: Starting the conversation with the school opens a powerful door to support your child effectively. üìö
emotion_q1: My child gets angry quickly at home and school. Why?
emotion_a1: Tantrums are often a way of expressing stress or confusion ‚Äî not simply bad behavior.
emotion_q2: Should I scold them when they‚Äôre angry?
emotion_a2: It‚Äôs better to embrace their feelings first, then explain acceptable behavior afterward.
emotion_q3: But sometimes they yell or run away.
emotion_a3: Understanding the behavior helps them. Say: "I know you‚Äôre angry. I‚Äôm here to help you."
emotion_a4: Every behavior has a feeling behind it‚Ä¶ and every feeling deserves to be understood and supported. üíõ
emotion_end_message: The more you understand your child‚Äôs emotions, the more they trust and cooperate with you. ‚ù§Ô∏è
dyslexia_q1: My child mixes letters while reading ‚Äî is this normal?
dyslexia_a1: It could be a sign of dyslexia. Practice spelling and slow pronunciation are important.
dyslexia_q2: Does it mean they won‚Äôt learn to read well?
dyslexia_a2: Not at all. With patience and repetition, children with dyslexia can improve significantly.
dyslexia_a3: Use illustrated stories, repeat words clearly, and encourage them even if they make mistakes.
dyslexia_a4: Every small step is a big achievement. Dyslexia isn‚Äôt failure‚Äîit‚Äôs just a different way of learning.
dyslexia_end_message: Well done! Understanding dyslexia is the first step to supporting your child with confidence. üåü
dyscalculia_q1: My child hates numbers and avoids math homework.
dyscalculia_a1: They might have dyscalculia ‚Äî difficulty understanding basic math operations.
dyscalculia_q2: How do I know it‚Äôs truly dyscalculia?
dyscalculia_a2: Look for trouble counting, forgetting how to add, or reversing numbers often.
dyscalculia_q3: What‚Äôs the first step to support them?
dyscalculia_a3: Start with fun visual tools like blocks and games ‚Äî avoid pressure.
dyscalculia_q4: Will they succeed in the future?
dyscalculia_a4: Yes! Many children overcome difficulties when given early support.
dyscalculia_end_message: Wonderful! Your support now makes a huge difference in your child‚Äôs future. üëè
support_finish: Thanks for reading. You are doing great!
